title: Nothing lasts forever: Why Forever 21 is closing its doors
text:
Company says it needs to adapt to a changing market

Dresses for $7 and jean jackets for $12?

What a steal — I mean, deal!

Those are some of the sales you could cash in on at Forever 21 right now.

But before you go blowing your allowance at the mall, you might want to take a few minutes to understand why the store is liquidating all its merchandise at rock-bottom prices.

"We really reuse stuff instead of just throwing them out." - Sophia Martucci, age 12

The news this week

Forever 21 is closing all its stores in Canada.

The American chain filed for bankruptcy protection in the U.S. and Canada.

What does that mean?

It means the company owes more money than it can pay and it’s asking for the opportunity to restructure.

So while the stores are closing in Canada and selling off all their stuff, this is not the absolute end of Forever 21.

Forever 21 is an American chain with stores all over the world, including this one, which opened in Sydney, Australia, in 2015. (Cameron Spencer/Getty Images)

It will keep selling products online and some stores will stay open in the U.S.

Eventually, the company could get back on its feet. Or it could shut down completely.

But it means that in Canada, the people who work in the stores will soon be out of a job.

Why did this happen?

There are several reasons.

In a statement, the company said it needs time to “reposition the brand and global business to adapt to the current retail environment.”

More people are shopping online, and only 16 per cent of Forever 21’s sales were online, according to bankruptcy filings.

The chain also expanded very quickly in the last few years into very large spaces that were not sustainable, said Farla Efros, president of the HRC Retail Advisory.

Forever 21’s initial success was in part thanks to its affordable merchandise, but that has ultimately been part of its undoing. (Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

Forever 21 is also one of the first companies to specialize in “fast fashion.”

That means it was quickly taking runway looks and putting them in stores at very affordable prices.

Sounds like a good deal, right? Wrong

The concept of fast fashion has been under fire lately because the clothes don’t last long and end up in landfills.

Basically, it’s bad for the environment and we know this is something kids are paying attention to.

Young people “are incredibly environmentally conscious," retail consultant Bruce Winder told CBC.

Take Sophia Martucci, for example. She attended the climate strike in Montreal on Sept. 27.

“My family, what we do, is we really reuse stuff instead of just throwing them out,” she said.

Sophia Martucci, 12, shops at stores that sell used clothing. (Franca G. Mignacca/CBC)

At the strike, she pointed to her mom’s sign about “how stuff now is not as well made, so it has to go in the garbage, but we go to [a used clothing store] and reuse clothes and stuff.”

Some other retailers that have closed in Canada in the past few years:

Payless Shoes.

American Apparel.

Jean Machine.

Gymboree.

Want to know more about fast fashion? Check out our video here.

With files from Pete Evans/CBC News
description: Clothing retailer Forever 21 announced this week it’s closing its stores in Canada after filing for bankruptcy protection.
